statement.tex: %text What is the minimum value (if any) of \[ \qquad \qquad y = \dfrac{x}{\ln x^2} \] \textbf{Note: }$\ln = \log_e$ (natural logarithm) %
\\ %text Given $\dfrac{dy}{dx}$, which of the following is true? %
\\ %text Going further, is the following true at the extrema point $x = e$? %

reason.tex:
\begin{align} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{\ln x - 1}{2\cdot \left(\ln x\right)^2} \\ \implies \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= 0\text{ when } \ln x - 1 = 0 \\ \implies \ln x &= 1\implies x = e \end{align}\\ %text
Therefore, an extrema occurs when $x=e$. %

options.tex: %text There is a minima at $x = e$. And the \underline\text{minimum} value is $y = \dfrac{e}{2}$. %
%text There is a maxima - not minima - at $x = e$. And the \underline\text{maximum} value is $y = \dfrac{e^2}{2}$. %

reason.tex: \begin{align} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= \dfrac{1}{2}\cdot \left[\dfrac{1}{\ln x}-\dfrac{1}{(\ln x)^2}\right]\\ \implies\dfrac{d^2 y}{dx^2} &= \dfrac{1}{2}\cdot \left[-\dfrac{1}{x\cdot (\ln x)^2} + \dfrac{2}{x\cdot (\ln x)^3}\right] \\ &= \dfrac{1}{2x\cdot (\ln x)^2}\cdot \left(\dfrac{2}{\ln x} - 1 \right) \\ \implies \left[\dfrac{d^2 y}{dx^2}\right]_{x=e} &= \dfrac{1}{2e\cdot (\ln e)^2}\cdot \left(\dfrac{2}{\ln e} - 1\right) \\ &= \dfrac{1}{2e}\gt 0\implies\text{ minima.} \\ \text{And so, }y_{MIN} &= \left[\dfrac{x}{\ln x^2}\right]_{x=e} = \dfrac{e}{2\ln e} = \dfrac{e}{2}. \end{align}
